title: Matthew Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 3.

questions.question: Where did John the Baptist preach according to Matthew 3:1?
questions.correctAnswer: In the wilderness of Judaea
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:1 states that John the Baptist was preaching in the wilderness of Judaea.

questions.question: What message did John the Baptist preach in Matthew 3:2?
options: Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand
questions.correctAnswer: Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:2 records John the Baptist preaching 'Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.'

questions.question: According to Matthew 3:4, what was John's clothing made of?
questions.correctAnswer: Camel's hair
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:4 describes John’s raiment as of camel's hair with a leathern girdle.

questions.question: Who came out to see John the Baptist as stated in Matthew 3:5?
options: Jerusalem, all Judaea, and all the region round about Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem, all Judaea, and all the region round about Jordan
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:5 says that people from Jerusalem, Judaea, and the surrounding Jordan region came to John.

questions.question: What did people do when they came to John in the Jordan according to Matthew 3:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Were baptized confessing their sins
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:6 states that people were baptized by John in the Jordan confessing their sins.

questions.question: What did John call the Pharisees and Sadducees in Matthew 3:7?
questions.correctAnswer: O generation of vipers
questions.explanation: In Matthew 3:7, John addresses the Pharisees and Sadducees as 'O generation of vipers.'

questions.question: What did John say should be brought forth according to Matthew 3:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Fruits meet for repentance
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:8 commands to bring forth fruits meet for repentance.

questions.question: In Matthew 3:9, what did John warn people not to rely on?
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham to be their father
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:9 warns not to say 'We have Abraham to our father,' meaning relying on heritage alone is insufficient.

questions.question: What is laid unto the root of the trees in Matthew 3:10?
questions.correctAnswer: The axe
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:10 states that the axe is laid unto the root of the trees, symbolizing judgment.

questions.question: Who did John say was mightier than him in Matthew 3:11?
questions.correctAnswer: He that cometh after me
questions.explanation: John says in Matthew 3:11 that the one coming after him is mightier and will baptize with the Holy Ghost and fire.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 3:13, Jesus came from Galilee to be baptized by John.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:13 clearly states that Jesus came from Galilee to Jordan to be baptized by John.

questions.question: True or False: John immediately baptized Jesus without any hesitation as per Matthew 3:14.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:14 shows John hesitated and said he needed to be baptized by Jesus instead.

questions.question: True or False: In Matthew 3:17, a voice from heaven said, 'This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:17 records the heavenly voice declaring Jesus as God's beloved Son, in whom He is well pleased.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance: but he that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to _______.' (Matthew 3:11)
questions.correctAnswer: bear
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:11 says John is not worthy to bear the shoes of the one coming after him.

questions.question: What descended upon Jesus like a dove after His baptism according to Matthew 3:16?
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of God
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:16 describes the Spirit of God descending like a dove upon Jesus after baptism.

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling unworthy to serve in church. Based on Matthew 3, what biblical truth about humility could you share?
options: John said he was not worthy to carry Jesus’ shoes
Jesus said he was the greatest in the kingdom
John claimed to be a prophet greater than Jesus
The Pharisees said they were holier than others
questions.correctAnswer: John said he was not worthy to carry Jesus’ shoes
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:11 shows John humbly acknowledging he is unworthy even to carry the shoes of Jesus, teaching us humility and recognizing our place before God.

questions.question: How does Matthew 3 teach us about the importance of repentance in Christian living?
options: John preached repentance because the kingdom of heaven is near
Jesus baptized people without asking for repentance
Repentance was only for the Pharisees and Sadducees
Repentance was optional according to John the Baptist
questions.correctAnswer: John preached repentance because the kingdom of heaven is near
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:2 emphasizes John's message to repent as the kingdom of heaven is at hand, showing that repentance is essential for entering God's kingdom (see also verses 8 and 11).

questions.question: A believer struggles with feeling justified by family heritage. What biblical truth from Matthew 3 would you share about this?
options: God can raise children of Abraham from stones
Only Pharisees are saved by birthright
Heritage is more important than fruitfulness
questions.correctAnswer: God can raise children of Abraham from stones
questions.explanation: In Matthew 3:9, John warns that relying on Abraham as an ancestor is not enough, because God can raise children for Abraham even from stones, emphasizing personal repentance and fruitfulness.

questions.question: How does Matthew 3 instruct us about the integrity of our actions as evidence of repentance?
options: Bring forth fruits meet for repentance
Claim you have Abraham as your father
Avoid baptism as it is symbolic only
questions.correctAnswer: Bring forth fruits meet for repentance
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:8 calls for genuine change by producing fruits worthy of repentance, teaching that true repentance results in changed actions, not just words (see also verses 10 and 12).

questions.question: What does Matthew 3 teach about dealing with temptation and judgment?
options: The axe is laid to the root of the trees, cutting down those who do not produce good fruit
Temptation should be ignored as it is not serious
Fruitless trees will be forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: The axe is laid to the root of the trees, cutting down those who do not produce good fruit
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:10 warns that every tree not producing good fruit will be cut down, illustrating God’s judgment on unrepentant sin and the importance of perseverance in holiness.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged about their spiritual progress. Based on Matthew 3, what encouragement about God's work in purification can you share?
options: Jesus will thoroughly purge his floor and gather the wheat
Believers must purify themselves without God
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus will thoroughly purge his floor and gather the wheat
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:12 describes Jesus’ role in purifying and gathering the righteous like wheat, encouraging believers that God actively cleanses and preserves His people.

questions.question: How does the baptism of Jesus in Matthew 3 model obedience and fulfilling righteousness?
options: Jesus insisted on being baptized to fulfill all righteousness
Jesus refused baptism because he was sinless
John baptized Jesus without his consent
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus insisted on being baptized to fulfill all righteousness
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:15 shows Jesus instructing John to baptize Him to fulfill all righteousness, demonstrating His obedience to God's plan and setting an example for believers to obey God’s commands.

questions.question: What does the descent of the Spirit like a dove at Jesus' baptism teach us about the nature of God's presence in Christian life?
options: God's Spirit comes gently and visibly to empower believers
The Spirit descends only on prophets
God's Spirit is invisible and never seen
The Spirit only comes after a believer dies
questions.correctAnswer: God's Spirit comes gently and visibly to empower believers
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:16 describes the Spirit descending like a dove, symbolizing God's gentle presence and empowerment for Jesus, which is a model for believers receiving the Holy Spirit for spiritual life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 3, John the Baptist welcomed the Pharisees and Sadducees to his baptism without any rebuke.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:7 records John calling the Pharisees and Sadducees a 'generation of vipers,' rebuking them for hypocrisy and warning them to produce fruit worthy of repentance.

questions.question: True or False: Matthew 3 teaches that baptism with water is sufficient for full spiritual cleansing.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:11 contrasts John's water baptism with the coming baptism by Jesus with the Holy Spirit and fire, showing that water baptism alone is not sufficient for full spiritual cleansing.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: John the Baptist wore raiment of __________ and a leathern girdle about his loins.
questions.correctAnswer: camel's hair
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:4 describes John's clothing as made of camel's hair, illustrating his simple, humble lifestyle and dedication to God.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand the importance of confession in repentance. Based on Matthew 3, what would you tell them?
options: People who were baptized confessed their sins to John
Confession is unnecessary if you feel sorry privately
Confession is only for public leaders
questions.correctAnswer: People who were baptized confessed their sins to John
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:6 states that many were baptized by John in the Jordan while confessing their sins, showing confession as part of genuine repentance and spiritual cleansing.

questions.question: How does Matthew 3 guide believers toward evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: John preached in the wilderness calling people to repentance
Evangelism was only for the apostles
Sharing the Gospel was forbidden in Judaea
John baptized secretly without public preaching
questions.correctAnswer: John preached in the wilderness calling people to repentance
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:1-2 shows John boldly preaching in the wilderness and calling people to repent because the kingdom of heaven is near, encouraging believers to share the Gospel with urgency.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline is modeled by John the Baptist's lifestyle in Matthew 3?
options: Simplicity and self-denial in daily living
questions.correctAnswer: Simplicity and self-denial in daily living
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:4 describes John's simple clothing and diet of locusts and wild honey, modeling self-denial and devotion, spiritual disciplines essential for focused Christian living.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with understanding God's approval. Based on Matthew 3, what truth about God's delight can you share?
options: God declared Jesus as His beloved Son in whom He was well pleased
God only approves those who perform miracles
Approval depends on wealth and status
God's approval is not expressed openly
questions.correctAnswer: God declared Jesus as His beloved Son in whom He was well pleased
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:17 records a voice from heaven affirming Jesus as God’s beloved Son, showing that God openly expresses approval and delight in obedience and righteousness.

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 3.

questions.question: What is the significance of John the Baptist's clothing described as camel's hair and a leathern girdle?
options: It symbolizes Elijah's prophetic attire and ascetic lifestyle
It represents the wealth of the priestly class
It is a mark of royal status
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Elijah's prophetic attire and ascetic lifestyle
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:4 describes John's raiment as camel's hair and a leathern girdle, which connects him typologically to Elijah, fulfilling Malachi's prophecy about Elijah's return before the Messiah (Malachi 4:5). This clothing signifies asceticism and prophetic authority.

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet is directly quoted in Matthew 3:3 regarding the voice crying in the wilderness?
questions.correctAnswer: Esaias (Isaiah)
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:3 explicitly cites the prophet Esaias, the Greek form of Isaiah, quoting Isaiah 40:3 to identify John as the voice preparing the way for the Lord.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'kingdom of heaven is at hand' imply about the eschatological expectations in Matthew 3:2?
options: The imminent arrival of God's reign on earth
A distant future event with no urgency
The establishment of a political kingdom in Judaea
The rejection of the Old Testament law
questions.correctAnswer: The imminent arrival of God's reign on earth
questions.explanation: In Matthew 3:2, 'kingdom of heaven is at hand' conveys an urgent call to repentance due to the nearness of God's sovereign rule, reflecting Jewish eschatological hope for divine intervention.

questions.question: In Matthew 3:6, what was the purpose of baptism performed by John?
options: Confession of sins and preparation for the coming kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Confession of sins and preparation for the coming kingdom
questions.explanation: Verse Matthew 3:6 states that people were baptized by John in the Jordan while confessing their sins, symbolizing repentance and readiness for God's imminent kingdom.

questions.question: In Matthew 3:7, John calls the Pharisees and Sadducees 'generation of vipers.' What literary device is this an example of?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Calling them a 'generation of vipers' (Matthew 3:7) is a metaphor portraying their dangerous and deceitful nature, rooted in Jewish prophetic tradition (e.g., Isaiah 59:5).

questions.question: What does John mean by 'fruits meet for repentance' in Matthew 3:8?
options: Actions and lifestyle changes that demonstrate genuine repentance
questions.correctAnswer: Actions and lifestyle changes that demonstrate genuine repentance
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:8 emphasizes that true repentance should produce visible ethical and moral transformation, not just verbal confession.

questions.question: How does John challenge the people’s reliance on Abraham as their spiritual heritage in Matthew 3:9?
options: By saying God can raise children of Abraham from stones
By telling them Abraham’s covenant is null
By forbidding them to mention Abraham
By requiring them to perform circumcision again
questions.correctAnswer: By saying God can raise children of Abraham from stones
questions.explanation: In Matthew 3:9, John warns against complacency in heritage by asserting God's power to create true descendants of Abraham from stones, highlighting spiritual lineage over physical ancestry.

questions.question: What eschatological imagery is used in Matthew 3:10 to describe judgment?
options: An axe laid to the root of trees and burning of unfruitful trees
A lion roaring in the wilderness
A trumpet sounding in the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: An axe laid to the root of trees and burning of unfruitful trees
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:10 uses the metaphor of an axe at the root of trees to signify imminent judgment and the burning of unfruitful trees to represent the fate of the unrighteous.

questions.question: What is the typological significance of John baptizing with water, while the coming one baptizes with the Holy Ghost and fire (Matthew 3:11)?
options: John’s baptism symbolizes repentance; Christ’s baptism symbolizes spiritual empowerment and purification
Both baptisms are identical in purpose and effect
Water baptism is for Jews; Spirit baptism is for Gentiles
John’s baptism is temporary; Christ’s baptism is obsolete
questions.correctAnswer: John’s baptism symbolizes repentance; Christ’s baptism symbolizes spiritual empowerment and purification
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:11 contrasts John’s water baptism for repentance with the coming Messiah's baptism by the Holy Spirit and fire, indicating a deeper, transformative spiritual cleansing.

questions.question: In Matthew 3:12, what does the imagery of the 'fan in his hand' and burning the chaff symbolize?
options: Divine judgment separating the righteous (wheat) from the wicked (chaff)
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment separating the righteous (wheat) from the wicked (chaff)
questions.explanation: The fan symbolizes Jesus’ role as judge who will separate true believers (wheat) from evildoers (chaff), burning the latter with unquenchable fire as stated in Matthew 3:12.

questions.question: Why does John initially refuse to baptize Jesus in Matthew 3:14?
options: Because John felt unworthy and believed Jesus should baptize him
Because Jesus was not yet repentant
Because John did not recognize Jesus
Because baptism was only for Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Because John felt unworthy and believed Jesus should baptize him
questions.explanation: John says in Matthew 3:14 that he needs to be baptized by Jesus, indicating his recognition of Jesus’ superior status and his own unworthiness.

questions.question: What theological purpose does Jesus’ baptism serve in Matthew 3:15?
options: To fulfill all righteousness, aligning with divine will and prophetic fulfillment
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill all righteousness, aligning with divine will and prophetic fulfillment
questions.explanation: Jesus states in Matthew 3:15 that his baptism is necessary to fulfill all righteousness, signifying obedience to God's plan and validation of John's ministry.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Spirit of God descending like a dove in Matthew 3:16?
options: It symbolizes the anointing and divine approval of Jesus’ mission
It is a common bird in Judaea with no symbolic meaning
It indicates Jesus’ submission to Jewish law
It signifies the presence of angels
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the anointing and divine approval of Jesus’ mission
questions.explanation: The dove in Matthew 3:16 is a visual symbol of the Holy Spirit descending, marking Jesus as the Messiah and affirming his divine authority.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the voice from heaven in Matthew 3:17 proclaiming Jesus as 'my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased'?
options: It confirms Jesus’ divine sonship and God's approval of his mission
It is a metaphor for the people's acceptance
It signals the end of the Old Testament covenant
It is a declaration of Jesus’ kingship over Rome
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms Jesus’ divine sonship and God's approval of his mission
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:17 records God's voice affirming Jesus as His beloved Son, thus publicly endorsing Jesus’ identity and mission within the divine plan.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 3:5-6, only the people of Jerusalem were baptized by John in the Jordan River.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Matthew 3:5-6 states that Jerusalem, all Judaea, and the region around Jordan went out to John and were baptized, indicating a broad geographical reach beyond just Jerusalem.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary message John the Baptist preached in the wilderness of Judaea?
options: Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand
Believe in Jesus as the Messiah
Prepare for the destruction of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand
questions.explanation: John's central call was repentance because the kingdom of heaven was near (Matthew 3:2). This echoes Old Testament calls to repentance (Isaiah 40:3), and anticipates the inauguration of God's kingdom (Mark 1:15, Luke 3:3).

questions.question: According to Matthew 3, how is John the Baptist described in terms of his clothing and diet?
options: Camel's hair garment, leather belt, locusts and wild honey
Linen robe, golden sash, bread and wine
Woolen cloak, rope belt, figs and olives
Silk tunic, silver belt, fish and bread
questions.correctAnswer: Camel's hair garment, leather belt, locusts and wild honey
questions.explanation: John's ascetic lifestyle, wearing camel's hair and a leather girdle and eating locusts and wild honey, aligns with the prophetic tradition of Elijah (2 Kings 1:8; Matthew 3:4). This symbolizes his role as a prophet calling people to repentance.

questions.question: What does John call the Pharisees and Sadducees who come to his baptism?
questions.correctAnswer: Generation of vipers
questions.explanation: John rebukes the Pharisees and Sadducees as a 'generation of vipers,' indicating their hypocrisy and need for genuine repentance (Matthew 3:7). This strong language is reminiscent of prophetic denunciations of Israel's leaders (Psalm 58:4, Isaiah 59:5).

questions.question: What does John say God is able to do with stones in relation to Abraham?
options: Raise up children to Abraham from these stones
questions.correctAnswer: Raise up children to Abraham from these stones
questions.explanation: John emphasizes that God can create true spiritual descendants of Abraham, even from stones, meaning physical descent is insufficient for covenant membership (Matthew 3:9). This reflects Old Testament themes of God’s sovereign power (Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 55:11).

questions.question: What does John say is laid to the root of the trees, signifying imminent judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: An axe
questions.explanation: John warns of judgment using the imagery of an axe laid to the root of trees, symbolizing imminent divine judgment on those not producing good fruit (Matthew 3:10), consistent with prophetic warnings (Jeremiah 10:3, Isaiah 10:33).

questions.question: How does John distinguish his baptism from the one who is to come after him?
options: John baptizes with water; the one to come will baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire
John baptizes with fire; the one to come will baptize with water
John baptizes with oil; the one to come will baptize with blood
John baptizes with water; the one to come will baptize with wine
questions.correctAnswer: John baptizes with water; the one to come will baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire
questions.explanation: John’s baptism is for repentance with water, whereas the Messiah will baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire, indicating a fuller spiritual purification and empowerment (Matthew 3:11). This anticipates Pentecost (Acts 2:3-4) and judgment (Malachi 3:2-3).

questions.question: What metaphor does John use to describe the Messiah’s judgment of the world?
options: A fan to thoroughly purge the floor, gathering wheat and burning chaff
A hammer to break the rocks
A sword to divide the people
A shepherd to lead the sheep
questions.correctAnswer: A fan to thoroughly purge the floor, gathering wheat and burning chaff
questions.explanation: John describes the Messiah’s judgment as separating wheat from chaff, purging the floor with a fan, symbolizing divine judgment that preserves the righteous and destroys the wicked (Matthew 3:12). This imagery is rooted in Old Testament agricultural metaphors (Psalm 1:4-5, Jeremiah 23:28).

questions.question: Why did John initially refuse to baptize Jesus?
options: He said he needed to be baptized by Jesus instead
He did not recognize Jesus as the Messiah
He was instructed only to baptize sinners
questions.correctAnswer: He said he needed to be baptized by Jesus instead
questions.explanation: John felt unworthy to baptize Jesus, acknowledging Jesus’ superiority and sinlessness, indicating John’s humility and recognition of Christ’s unique role (Matthew 3:14). This reflects John’s prophetic awareness of Jesus’ divine identity (John 1:29).

questions.question: What reason does Jesus give for allowing John to baptize Him?
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill all righteousness
questions.explanation: Jesus says that it is proper to fulfill all righteousness through baptism, emphasizing His obedience to God's plan and identification with humanity (Matthew 3:15). This shows Jesus’ role in God's redemptive plan (Philippians 2:8).

questions.question: What miraculous sign occurs immediately after Jesus is baptized?
options: The heavens opened and the Spirit of God descended like a dove
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens opened and the Spirit of God descended like a dove
questions.explanation: After Jesus' baptism, the heavens opened and the Spirit descended like a dove on Him, signifying divine approval and the anointing of the Holy Spirit (Matthew 3:16). This fulfillment of prophecy echoes Isaiah 42:1 and Psalm 2:7.

questions.question: How does God identify Jesus at His baptism?
options: As His beloved Son, in whom He is well pleased
As a great prophet and teacher
As a humble servant of God
As the promised Messiah to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: As His beloved Son, in whom He is well pleased
questions.explanation: God’s voice declares Jesus as His beloved Son, pleased with Him (Matthew 3:17), affirming Jesus’ divine Sonship and messianic mission, consistent with Psalm 2:7 and Isaiah 42:1.

questions.question: What does John instruct the people to produce as evidence of their repentance?
questions.correctAnswer: Fruits meet for repentance
questions.explanation: John demands tangible evidence of repentance in the form of good fruits, not relying on heritage alone (Matthew 3:8). This teaching aligns with prophetic calls for righteousness (Isaiah 1:16-17, Luke 3:8).

questions.question: What geographical region did people come from to hear John and be baptized?
options: Jerusalem, all Judaea, and the region around Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: Jerusalem, all Judaea, and the region around Jordan
questions.explanation: People from Jerusalem, Judaea, and the surrounding Jordan region came to John, indicating the widespread impact of his ministry (Matthew 3:5). This reflects the fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy about preparing the way (Isaiah 40:3).

questions.question: What does John say will happen to every tree that does not bear good fruit?
options: It will be cut down and cast into the fire
It will be transplanted into poor soil
It will be blessed with more rain
It will be pruned to grow better
questions.correctAnswer: It will be cut down and cast into the fire
questions.explanation: John warns that trees without good fruit will be cut down and burned, symbolizing judgment on those who fail to repent (Matthew 3:10). This judgment motif is consistent with the prophetic tradition (Jeremiah 11:16, Malachi 4:1).

questions.question: How does John describe his own worthiness in relation to the one who is to come after him?
options: He is not worthy to bear His shoes
questions.correctAnswer: He is not worthy to bear His shoes
questions.explanation: John acknowledges his unworthiness even to carry the Messiah’s shoes (Matthew 3:11), highlighting Christ’s supreme dignity and divine mission (Philippians 2:7-8).
